p: The impacts of climate change are occurring against a backdrop where children and youth are currently experiencing considerable mental health issues for their age group, and are “feeling less in control of their lives than at any point in recent history” [33]. The literature shows that youth are often aware of the impact climate change has on their lives and the planet, and that they use a variety of mechanisms (adaptive and maladaptive) to cope with these realities. Children and youth below the voting age may also feel frustration with their perceived inability to participate democratically [34]. In addition, children and youth’s perceptions of climate change-related risk varies across several markers of privilege and social locations [35].
